showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0001.name: Geomap of Order Locations
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0001.description: Order To Activation Geomapping of our completed orders for our prepaid mobile services. This includes NEW and TOPUP prepaid services.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0001.relevance: A visual representation of where our orders have been being placed. Using this information the business can make more informed decisions about where to increase Retail Capacity and during what times this would have the most impact. For example, at the airport during arrival times of flights from certain countries that have a large prepaid purchase history.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0001.operationalize: This search gives us insight to where our activations / services are being purchased from. From a business perspective, this gives us a general understanding of where our customers are purchasing services and where we could potentially increase capacity for retail space.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0001.howToImplement: For this search, our data source for the transactions need to have a location. We then enrich that location data with a lookup that contains the latitude and longitude, and then we map this out with Splunk's geostats command.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0001.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0001.sampleSPL: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | fields orderLocation | lookup prepaid_locations orderLocation | geostats count latfield=lat longfield=lon binspanlat=19 binspanlong=19

visualizations.title: 02A Geomapping of Orders by Count
visualizations.search: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | fields orderLocation | lookup prepaid_locations orderLocation | geostats count latfield=lat longfield=lon binspanlat=19 binspanlong=19

showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0002.name: Top Purchasing Countries of New Prepaid Services
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0002.description: Order To Activation Chart of our top purchasing countries.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0002.relevance: A visual representation of where top net-new purchases are originating from. Using this information the business can make more informed decisions about where to increase Marketing Campaignes and during what times this would have the most impact. For example, during Christmas in Western Countries, or during Chinese New Years.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0002.operationalize: This search gives us insight to where our net-new customers are from based on their Order Details. From a business perspective, this gives us an understanding of where our customers are from and how marketing or campaigns could drive business.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0002.howToImplement: For this search, our data source for the transactions need to be enriched with information about the customer. In this example a billing system, and regulatory requirements, have us record either a Passport or Federal ID for the customer. We then use this data point with each transaction and chart this.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0002.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0002.sampleSPL: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | fields iDCountry orderType | search orderType="NEW" | eval iDCountry=upper(iDCountry) | top iDCountry

visualizations.title: 02A Top New Prepaid Purchasing Countries
visualizations.search: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | fields iDCountry orderType | search orderType="NEW" | eval iDCountry=upper(iDCountry) | top iDCountry

showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0003.name: Volume of Types of Orders by Time
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0003.description: Visual representation of our services that are being purchased over time.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0003.relevance: A visual representation of what we sold over the specified time range. This example allows the business to make an informed decisions about what services are being sold over time. .
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0003.operationalize: This search gives us insight to what services our customers are purchasng based on their Order Details. From a business perspective, this gives us an understanding of what our customers want and how marketing or campaigns could drive business.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0003.howToImplement: For this search, our data source for the transactions needs have a ordertype field which must correspond to the Service Description of what is being sold.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0003.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0003.sampleSPL: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | eval _time=strptime(timestamp, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | fields _time orderType orderLocation IdType customerIdNumber | search orderType="*" | timechart fixedrange=false span=30m count by orderType

visualizations.title: O2A Timechart of Ordertypes

showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0004.name: Top Selling Services / SKUs within our Service Catalog.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0004.description: This shows us our top selling Services / SKUs over a specified time period.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0004.relevance: A visual representation of our top selling Packages. This example allows the business to make an informed decisions about what the most popular services are that have been sold over time.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0004.operationalize: This search gives us insight to what services our customers are purchasing based on their Order Details. From a business perspective, this gives us an understanding of what our customers want and how marketing or campaigns could drive business.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0004.howToImplement: For this search, our data source for the transactions needs have a successful transaction status and product. We then enrich the data with a description of that product SKU from a lookup that has SKU's mapped to a friendly name.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0004.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0004.sampleSPL: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | fields _time productSKU transactionStatus | search transactionStatus="SUCCESS" | lookup prepaid_o2a_products productSKU | top description

visualizations.title: O2A Top Selling Packages
visualizations.search: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | fields _time productSKU transactionStatus | search transactionStatus="SUCCESS" | lookup prepaid_o2a_products productSKU | top description

showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0005.name: End-To-End Transactional Status Overview
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0005.description: End-to-End Transaction Status of the Order to Activation Process of our Services.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0005.relevance: This example gives us the End-to-End status, over time, of our Order to Activation Process. This example shows us the successful, or failed attempts for customers purchasing or renewing services. This is gives us general insight into how our O2A process is working with a visual representation of status. We might recognize a high number of failures as some form of system outage, or problem that needs to be investigated.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0005.operationalize: This search gives us a timeline for our activations and a visual representation of successful vs failed activations. With this information, we can determine if there is a service delivery issue within our O2A processes, or if there are issues with a particular network or component.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0005.howToImplement: For this search, our data source for the transactions needs have a transaction status that indicates either a success, or a failure. We then chart these over time.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0005.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0005.sampleSPL: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | eval _time=strptime(timestamp, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | fields _time transactionStatus | timechart span=10m fixedrange=false count by transactionStatus

visualizations.title: O2A End-To-End Transactional Status Overtime
visualizations.search: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | eval _time=strptime(timestamp, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | fields _time transactionStatus | timechart span=10m fixedrange=false count by transactionStatus

showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0006.name: Business Process Errors Over Time within our O2A Workflow.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0006.description: Order to Activation Errors by Process within our Business Workflow.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0006.relevance: This example gives us a By-Process Error Count of orders as they flow through our Order to Activation Processes over time. This is important because most Telco's and Service Providers have a large number of processes in their O2A workflows, and very few have the ability to monitor transactions as they flow through the various systems typically due to large numbers of custom and homegrown applications in use. Having this insight allows a business to very quickly trouble shoot where a problem is occuring. For example, understanding if the problem comes from a Service Activation System, or a Inventory Fullfilment System, is extremely beneficial to maintain good service and happy customers.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0006.operationalize: This search gives us a trellis timeline and count for our activations by a per process chart. With this information, we can determine if there is an issue within a specific O2A process and fix this with minimal impact.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0006.howToImplement: For this search, our data source for the transactions needs have a transaction status that indicates either a success, or a failure by process. This example has 4 business processes included as an example ( Billing Systems, Inventory and Fullfilment, Service Activation, and CRM.) In reality there will be many more then 4 processes, but this search can easily be expand by including the data sources for the extra processes into the search.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0006.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0006.sampleSPL: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | eval _time=strptime(timestamp, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | fields _time p1* p2* p3* p4* | eval p1=case(p1Status=="OK",0,1=1,"1"), p2=case(p2Status=="OK",0,1=1,"1"), p3=case(p3Status=="OK",0,1=1,"1"),p4=case(p4Status=="OK",0,1=1,"1") | eventstats sum(p1) AS p1cnt sum(p2) AS p2cnt sum(p3) AS p3cnt sum(p4) AS p4cnt by _time | timechart fixedrange=false span=10m sum(p1cnt) AS "Billing Systems" sum(p2cnt) as "Fullfilment" sum(p3cnt) AS "Service Activation" sum(p4cnt) AS "CRM"

visualizations.title: 02A By Process Errors over Time
visualizations.search: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | eval _time=strptime(timestamp, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | fields _time p1* p2* p3* p4* | eval p1=case(p1Status=="OK",0,1=1,"1"), p2=case(p2Status=="OK",0,1=1,"1"), p3=case(p3Status=="OK",0,1=1,"1"),p4=case(p4Status=="OK",0,1=1,"1") | eventstats sum(p1) AS p1cnt sum(p2) AS p2cnt sum(p3) AS p3cnt sum(p4) AS p4cnt by _time | timechart fixedrange=false span=10m sum(p1cnt) AS "Billing Systems" sum(p2cnt) as "Fullfilment" sum(p3cnt) AS "Service Activation" sum(p4cnt) AS "CRM"

showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0007.id: Provisioning and Activation Errors by Type
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0007.name: Provisioning and Activation Errors with Enriched Details.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0007.description: Provisioning and Activation Errors by Type within the Service Activation Process and with Enriched Error Messages.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0007.relevance: This example gives us a Service Activation Process view of errors over time with a more human readable description of the error. With this information, we have the capability to understand where within the Service Activation process we are encountering problems, and what teams to work with in order to resolve these.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0007.operationalize: This search gives us a easy view of what errors we are having within the Service Activation Process. With this information, we can determine how to quickly troubleshoot and resolve technology specific problems within the Process (in this example the Service Activation Process.)
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0007.howToImplement: For this search, our data source for the transactions needs have a transaction failure status within the Process (in this case Service Activation.) Additionally, there should be a error code to human friendly description mapping that is used to enrich the source data for the final view.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0007.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0007.sampleSPL: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | eval _time=strptime(timestamp, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | search p3Status="FAIL" | fields _time p3* customer* | lookup prepaid_mobile_errors pMessage AS p3Message | stats count values(pDetails) AS "FailureReason" values(p3Message) AS "ErrorMessage" by _time | search count > 0 | stats sum(count) AS count by FailureReason ErrorMessage | xyseries   ErrorMessage FailureReason count

examples.name: Provisioning and Activation Errors by Type
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: Provisioning and Activation Errors by Type
visualizations.search: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | eval _time=strptime(timestamp, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | search p3Status="FAIL" | fields _time p3* customer* | lookup prepaid_mobile_errors pMessage AS p3Message | stats count values(pDetails) AS "FailureReason" values(p3Message) AS "ErrorMessage" by _time | search count > 0 | stats sum(count) AS count by FailureReason ErrorMessage | xyseries   ErrorMessage FailureReason count

showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0008.name: Order and Provisioning Errors with Customer ID
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0008.description: Order To Activation Order and Provision Errors with Customer ID and Additional Information.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0008.relevance: This search provides a report of Order and Provisioning Errors that have occured. In this, we have additional details such as the location of the failed transaction, Customer Identifier, Error Code and Error Context, and associated Order Numbers / Transaction IDs.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0008.operationalize: This search gives us insight to what errors our activations / services are failing with. Operationally this is important for us to understand what impact these errors have to our customers, or if these are expected errors. E.g., If TopUp/Refills are failing, then there is revenue lost or if we have a customer trying to by more SIMs then regulations allow.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0008.howToImplement: This search will require O2A log data from billing, activations, and CMS data. In this example, we have failed transactions, locations of the failed transactions, and error code and a lookup to map this error code to a human understandable message, along with some additional information around the User and the Trasnsaction IDs / Order IDs that failed.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0008.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0008.sampleSPL: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | eval _time=strptime(timestamp, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | search p3Status="FAIL" | fields _time p3* customer* order* | lookup prepaid_mobile_errors pMessage AS p3Message | stats count values(pDetails) AS "Error Details" values(customerIdNumber) AS "Customer ID Number" values(orderTracking) AS "Order Tracking" by customerID | sort - count | rename count AS Count customerID AS "Customer ID" | fields "Customer ID" "Customer ID Number" "Error Details" "Order Tracking" Count

visualizations.title: 02A Provisioning Errors by Customer ID
visualizations.search: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | eval _time=strptime(timestamp, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | search p3Status="FAIL" | fields _time p3* customer* order* | lookup prepaid_mobile_errors pMessage AS p3Message | stats count values(pDetails) AS "Error Details" values(customerIdNumber) AS "Customer ID Number" values(orderTracking) AS "Order Tracking" by customerID | sort - count | rename count AS Count customerID AS "Customer ID" | fields "Customer ID" "Customer ID Number" "Error Details" "Order Tracking" Count

showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0009.name: Regulatory - Activation Errors due to Potential SIM Abuse.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0009.description: Activations that have failed because of regulatory requirements or policy. In this case, we have a limitation to the number of SIMs a user can own on a network.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0009.relevance: This search provides a report of Order and Provisioning Errors that have occured based on a threshold of active / registered SIMs in the systems we are collecting data from. This provides a report for the associated customer details such as their Customer Identification, number associated to the activation, Order / Transaction ID(s), and where applicable a location where the transaction was attemped.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0009.operationalize: In the case where there are regulatory and reporting requirement, wheter by law or just internal, a report like this can be used to provide more details on the transacrtions in question. In this example, our carrier has a reporting requirement where users can only own three (3) SIMS on their network. This report shows where User's are trying to purchase / activate over the threshhold. This kind of report can be automated and warnings can be sent to the user's email address, phone number, order process, or if the transaction is in a physical location an alert can be posted.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0009.howToImplement: This search will require O2A log data from billing, activations, and CMS data. In this example, we have failed transactions, locations of the failed transactions, a specific error code (SIM Count Failure) and a lookup to map this error code to a human understandable message, along with some additional information around the User and the Trasnsaction IDs / Order IDs that failed.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0009.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0009.sampleSPL: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | eval _time=strptime(timestamp, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | search p3Status="FAIL" | fields _time p3* customer* order* | lookup prepaid_mobile_errors pMessage AS p3Message | search p3Message="ERROR-B993" | lookup prepaid_locations orderLocation OUTPUT description | stats count values(customerIdNumber) AS customerIdNumber values(orderTracking) AS orderTracking values(pDetails) as Details list(description) AS Location by customerID | sort - count

visualizations.title: 02A Compliance Reporting - Potential SIM Abuse
visualizations.search: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | eval _time=strptime(timestamp, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | search p3Status="FAIL" | fields _time p3* customer* order* | lookup prepaid_mobile_errors pMessage AS p3Message | search p3Message="ERROR-B993" | lookup prepaid_locations orderLocation OUTPUT description | stats count values(customerIdNumber) AS customerIdNumber values(orderTracking) AS orderTracking values(pDetails) as Details list(description) AS Location by customerID | sort - count

showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0010.name: Daily Revenue for Mobile Services.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0010.description: This example shows how to associate a monetary value to each transaction and gives us an estimated total daily revenue stream.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0010.relevance: This example shows how to associate a monetary value to each transaction and gives us an estimated total daily revenue stream.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0010.operationalize: Understanding the costs associated with each transaction and the revenue generated daily provides us real-time insight into our business. Here we take this further by showing the revenue as a trend compared to the previous day.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0010.howToImplement: This search will require O2A log data from billing, activations, and CMS data, in addition to this we also have a historic revenue record for the previous week and a per product price. In this example, we take the successful transactions, append the historic daily revenue for comparison, and add a unit price for the product/SKUs sold. We then summate this for the time range and use a trending single value display to visualise the results.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0010.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0010.sampleSPL: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | append [ inputlookup prepaid_previous_revenue | rename date AS timestamp totalRevenue AS price | fields timestamp price ] | eval _time=strptime(timestamp, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | lookup prepaid_o2a_products productSKU OUTPUT price | timechart fixedrange=false sum(price) AS totalSold

visualizations.title: O2A - Estimated Daily Revenue
visualizations.search: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | append [ inputlookup prepaid_previous_revenue | rename date AS timestamp totalRevenue AS price | fields timestamp price ] | eval _time=strptime(timestamp, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | lookup prepaid_o2a_products productSKU OUTPUT price | timechart fixedrange=false sum(price) AS totalSold

showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0013.name: Retail locations with potential staffing issues.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0013.description: This example shows how to identify where there maybe potential loss in revenue due to insufficient retail personnel.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0013.relevance: This example shows how to identify where there maybe potential loss in revenue due to insufficient retail personnel.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0013.operationalize: Most retail outlets measure metrics related to how long a transaction takes to complete and how it relates to customer experience. When customers experience times that are above our average transaction times, we can expect that there will be a potential for loss of revenue. Understanding our transaction times at retail locations can help forecast when more manpower is needed. This gives us real-time insight into our business.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0013.howToImplement: This search will require O2A log data from billing, activations, and CMS data. In this example, we take the transactions and add the location data to each event. We then calculate a transaction duration based on when a previous transaction is finished and when the current ends. We then filter based on our metrics, transactions that lasted more then 5 minutes, but less then 25. We then use timechart and reformat the results in a more human friendly view.
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0013.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_prepaid_mobile_search0013.sampleSPL: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | eval _time=strptime(timestamp, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | fields _time orderLocation orderType productSKU transactionStatus | lookup prepaid_locations orderLocation OUTPUT description | search description="Store1*" | sort 0 _time | streamstats window=1 current=false last(_time) AS previousTime | eval transactionDuration = ( _time - previousTime ) / 60 | eval transactionDuration = round(transactionDuration,2) | where transactionDuration < 25 | stats values(transactionDuration) as transactionDur values(_time) AS startTime values(orderLocation) AS orderLocation values(orderType) AS orderType values(transactionStatus) AS transactionStatus by description _time | where transactionDur > 5 | rename description AS "Location" transactionDur AS "Duration" | fields Location Duration _time startTime | timechart fixedrange=false span=1h count list(Duration) AS Duration list(startTime) as Times list(Location) AS Location | convert ctime(Times) timeformat="%Y/%m/%d %H:%M:%S" | table _time Location  Times Duration count

visualizations.title: O2A - Retail Staffing Issues
visualizations.search: | inputlookup prepaid_o2a_logs | eval _time=strptime(timestamp, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | fields _time orderLocation orderType productSKU transactionStatus | lookup prepaid_locations orderLocation OUTPUT description | search description="Store1*" | sort 0 _time | streamstats window=1 current=false last(_time) AS previousTime | eval transactionDuration = ( _time - previousTime ) / 60 | eval transactionDuration = round(transactionDuration,2) | where transactionDuration < 25 | stats values(transactionDuration) as transactionDur values(_time) AS startTime values(orderLocation) AS orderLocation values(orderType) AS orderType values(transactionStatus) AS transactionStatus by description _time | where transactionDur > 5 | rename description AS "Location" transactionDur AS "Duration" | fields Location Duration _time startTime | timechart fixedrange=false span=1h count list(Duration) AS Duration list(startTime) as Times list(Location) AS Location | convert ctime(Times) timeformat="%Y/%m/%d %H:%M:%S" | table _time Location  Times Duration count

showcase_cdn_search0001.id: Cache Hit Ratio by Number of Requests
showcase_cdn_search0001.help: Cache Hit Ratio by Number of Requests
showcase_cdn_search0001.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data for a total message size transferred per request, the content provider / identifier, and the status of the content. E,g., if the requested content is cached, or not.
showcase_cdn_search0001.operationalize: Having an understanding of how much content is being delivered by CDN Caches allows us to understand how to better operationalize our networks for Content Delivery.
showcase_cdn_search0001.relevance: This analyzes your CDN logs and gives you an understanding of the amount of your content that is being accessed from Cached Content based on number of requests.
showcase_cdn_search0001.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=Cache Hit Ratio by Number of Requests
showcase_cdn_search0001.description: Ratio of Requests that are accessing content from Cache Network, and not directly from the central content provider.
showcase_cdn_search0001.name: Cache Hit Ratio by Number of Requests
showcase_cdn_search0001.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | fields _time messageBytes cached cp | stats count values(messageBytes) AS totalBytes by _time cp cached | stats sum(count) AS totalRequests sum(totalBytes) as totalBytes by cached  | stats sum(totalRequests) as totalRequested sum(eval(totalRequests*if(cached=="true",1,0))) as "cached" | eval cacheRequestedHitRatio=round(cached/totalRequested * 100, 2) | fields cacheRequestedHitRatio

examples.name: Cache Hit Ratio by Number of Requests
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: Cache Hit Ratio by Number of Requests
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | fields _time messageBytes cached cp | stats count values(messageBytes) AS totalBytes by _time cp cached | stats sum(count) AS totalRequests sum(totalBytes) as totalBytes by cached  | stats sum(totalRequests) as totalRequested sum(eval(totalRequests*if(cached=="true",1,0))) as "cached" | eval cacheRequestedHitRatio=round(cached/totalRequested * 100, 2) | fields cacheRequestedHitRatio

showcase_cdn_search0002.id: Cache Hit Ratio by Amount of Traffic
showcase_cdn_search0002.description: Ratio of Traffic that is accessing the Cache, and not directly from the central content provider.
showcase_cdn_search0002.relevance: This search shows us what ratio of our traffic is accessing cached content.
showcase_cdn_search0002.operationalize: This search gives us insight to what ratio of the traffic for our Content is coming from our Caches. Based on the value of this, the business can make informed decisions about where to increase, or decrease, caching capabilities.
showcase_cdn_search0002.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data for a total message size transferred per request, and the status of the content. E,g., if the requested content is cached, or not.
showcase_cdn_search0002.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_cdn_search0002.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=Cache Hit Ratio by Amount of Traffic
showcase_cdn_search0002.name: Cache Hit Ratio by Amount of Traffic
showcase_cdn_search0002.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | fields _time messageBytes cached | stats sum(messageBytes) as "totalBytes", sum(eval(messageBytes * if(cached=="true",1,0))) as "cachedBytes" | eval cacheTrafficHitRatio=round(cachedBytes/totalBytes*100,2) | fields cacheTrafficHitRatio

examples.name: Cache Hit Ratio by Amount of Traffic
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: Cache Hit Ratio by Amount of Traffic
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | fields _time messageBytes cached | stats sum(messageBytes) as "totalBytes", sum(eval(messageBytes * if(cached=="true",1,0))) as "cachedBytes" | eval cacheTrafficHitRatio=round(cachedBytes/totalBytes*100,2) | fields cacheTrafficHitRatio

showcase_cdn_search0003.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data for a total message size transferred per request, and the status of the content. E,g., if the requested content is cached, or not.

showcase_cdn_search0004.description: The total amount of traffic served by the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0004.relevance: This example shows us the total amount of data transferred out the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0004.operationalize: This search gives us an understanding of the total amount of traffic our CDN has served. Based on the value of this, the business can make informed decisions about when and where to increase, or decrease, caching capabilities.
showcase_cdn_search0004.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data for a total message size transferred per request.
showcase_cdn_search0004.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_cdn_search0004.name: CDN Total Amount of Traffic
showcase_cdn_search0004.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | fields _time messageBytes | stats sum(messageBytes) as totalTrafficBytes | eval totalTrafficGBytes=totalTrafficBytes/pow(10,9) | fields totalTrafficGBytes

visualizations.title: CDN Total Amount of Traffic

showcase_cdn_search0005.id: CDN Total Number of Errors Over Time
showcase_cdn_search0005.description: The total number of Errors Over Time for the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0005.relevance: This example shows us the total number of errors over time for the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0005.operationalize: This search gives us an understanding of the total number of HTTP errors to our CDN. Where these values are high gives us insight to where we maybe having hardware, software, or general content delivery issues. Being able to identify these quickly, and resolve the problems is great for business.
showcase_cdn_search0005.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data for a http response code. At a minimum you need http response codes 400+.
showcase_cdn_search0005.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_cdn_search0005.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=CDN Total Number of Errors Over Time
showcase_cdn_search0005.name: CDN Total Number of Errors Over Time
showcase_cdn_search0005.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %T" mktime(_time) AS _time | sort 0 _time | fields _time messageBytes cached cp status | eval statusFailed=if(status >= 400, 1, 0) | search statusFailed="1" | timechart fixedrange=false span=1m sum(statusFailed) AS "Error Events"

examples.name: CDN Total Number of Errors Over Time
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: CDN Total Number of Errors Over Time
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %T" mktime(_time) AS _time | sort 0 _time | fields _time messageBytes cached cp status | eval statusFailed=if(status >= 400, 1, 0) | search statusFailed="1" | timechart fixedrange=false span=1m sum(statusFailed) AS "Error Events"

Being able to identify these quickly, and resolve the problems is great for business.

showcase_cdn_search0009.id: CDN Average Bandwidth Used Over Time
showcase_cdn_search0009.description: Find the Average Bandwidth being used for downloading content from the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0009.relevance: This gives us a visual representation of how much bandwidth is being used to consume content from the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0009.operationalize: Understanding how much bandwidth requests are using allows us to make more informed decisions about capacity and planning for the network.
showcase_cdn_search0009.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data for the amount of data downloaded and the total time it took for the download to complete.
showcase_cdn_search0009.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_cdn_search0009.name: CDN Average Bandwidth Used Over Time
showcase_cdn_search0009.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %T" mktime(_time) AS _time | fields _time messageBytes netPerfdownloadTime| sort 0 _time | eval bandwidthUsedMbps = ((messageBytes/netPerfdownloadTime)*1000/1024/128) | timechart fixedrange=false span=1m avg(bandwidthUsedMbps) AS avgBandwidthUsedMbps

examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: CDN Average Bandwidth Used Over Time

showcase_cdn_search0010.id: CDN Average Last Mile Round Trip Time
showcase_cdn_search0010.description: This example gives us the average round trip time for the "last mile" of the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0010.relevance: For Telco's offering CDN, monitoring roundtrip times of "the last mile" is beneficial for content delivery.
showcase_cdn_search0010.operationalize: Understanding latency from the backhaul network to the "last mile", or Edge Servers / CPE, enables informed decisions about capacity management and planning.
showcase_cdn_search0010.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data for the round trip time of what's defined as the Last Mile equipment. Typically this kind of data doesn't come from application logs, but from network monitoring tools or custom alerting solutions.
showcase_cdn_search0010.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_cdn_search0010.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=CDN Average Last Mile Round Trip Time
showcase_cdn_search0010.name: CDN Average Last Mile Round Trip Time
showcase_cdn_search0010.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | sort 0 _time | fields _time netPerflastMileRTT | stats avg(netPerflastMileRTT) AS avgLastMileRTT | eval avgLastMileRTT=round(avgLastMileRTT,3)

showcase_cdn_search0011.description: This example gives us the Edge / Region CDN's with the highest/slowest response times.
showcase_cdn_search0011.relevance: Understanding network behavior is a business priority. Being able to identify where Edge delivery is being impacted, or degredated, and remediate it is critical.
showcase_cdn_search0011.operationalize: If we can identify when Regions / Edges are experiencing high response times and degredation in services, we can better troubleshoot and remediate these issues. We can also use this to further understand regional user behavior and aid in forcasting network capacity.
showcase_cdn_search0011.howToImplement: This search requires that you have CDN applications logs that have time series data for the response time and ip data for clients accessing the CDN.
showcase_cdn_search0011.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_cdn_search0011.name: CDN High Latency Edge Networks
showcase_cdn_search0011.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | sort 0 _time | fields _time responseTime requestClientIp | iplocation requestClientIp | eval City=case(City=="","Unknown",1=1,City) | eval Region=case(Region=="","Unknown",1=1,Region) | eval HostingEdge = Region." - ".Country | stats avg(responseTime) AS avgResponseTime by HostingEdge | eval "Average Response Time"=round(avgResponseTime,3) | rename HostingEdge AS "Edge Hosting Region"| sort - "Average Response Time" | fields "Edge Hosting Region" "Average Response Time"

visualizations.title: CDN High Latency Edge Networks
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdn_general_operations | eval time=strptime(_time,"%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | sort 0 _time | fields _time responseTime requestClientIp | iplocation requestClientIp | eval City=case(City=="","Unknown",1=1,City) | eval Region=case(Region=="","Unknown",1=1,Region) | eval HostingEdge = Region." - ".Country | stats avg(responseTime) AS avgResponseTime by HostingEdge | eval "Average Response Time"=round(avgResponseTime,3) | rename HostingEdge AS "Edge Hosting Region"| sort - "Average Response Time" | fields "Edge Hosting Region" "Average Response Time"

showcase_physical_search0001.howToImplement:
This search relies on a RFID / Proximity badge reader system logs and lookup tables that provide further enrichment around the User-to-Badges, Error Codes, and a Reader to Card locations.

With this data available, you can substitute in sourcetype and lookup tables to use this search.
showcase_physical_search0001.operationalize: This search allows us to "monitor" a specific badge as it is used around monitored facilities. This could be used for a variety of reasons such as: Activity Logging, Compliance, Regulatory Reporting, and HR Related Requests.
showcase_physical_search0001.relevance: This search takes data logged from RFID / Proxmity badge readers, enriches it with facilties and logging information, and then shows activity for a designated badge.
showcase_physical_search0001.description: Track a badge on it's journey through a designated time period.
showcase_physical_search0001.name: Security Auditing - Badge Monitoring
showcase_physical_search0001.sampleSPL: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUTNEW status | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description | lookup physical_card_user_mapping cardId AS badgeId OUTPUTNEW firstName lastName emailAddress employeeId note officeId | search employeeId="25020002" | fields - badgereaderId,envAlarm,errorCode,powerStatus | eval fullName = firstName+" "+lastName | fields _time badgeId employeeId fullName officeId description status note | rename badgeId AS "Badge ID #" employeeId AS "Employee Number" fullName AS "Employee Name" officeId AS "Home Office" description AS "Card Reader Location" status AS "Read Status" note AS "Additional Notes.."

visualizations.title: User Tracking by Security
visualizations.search: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUTNEW status | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description | lookup physical_card_user_mapping cardId AS badgeId OUTPUTNEW firstName lastName emailAddress employeeId note officeId | search employeeId="25020002" | fields - badgereaderId,envAlarm,errorCode,powerStatus | eval fullName = firstName+" "+lastName | fields _time badgeId employeeId fullName officeId description status note | rename badgeId AS "Badge ID #" employeeId AS "Employee Number" fullName AS "Employee Name" officeId AS "Home Office" description AS "Card Reader Location" status AS "Read Status" note AS "Additional Notes.."

showcase_physical_search0002.howToImplement:
This search relies on a RFID / Proximity badge reader system logs and lookup tables that provide further enrichment around the User-to-Badges and a Reader to Card locations.

With this data available, you can substitute in sourcetype and lookup tables to use this search.
showcase_physical_search0002.operationalize: Auditing of Physical Access is a requirement for many regulatory bodies and industrial certifications. Being able to associate ingress and egress traffic for designated rooms and zones, to badges, in near real-time expedites compliance and security.
showcase_physical_search0002.relevance: This examples searches RFID / Proximity logs for access to certain facilties and rooms. Reporting from this can be used for Security, Compliance, or Customer Reporting Requirements.
showcase_physical_search0002.description: Audit and Report on Room Access in a secure facility based on badge readers.
showcase_physical_search0002.name: Security Auditing - Secure Facilties Access
showcase_physical_search0002.sampleSPL: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description active | lookup physical_card_user_mapping cardId AS badgeId | search description="LV-DC-2-DC-003-*" | stats count list(description) AS Room list(status) AS Status list(badgeId) AS BadgeID list(employeeId) AS userId by _time | eval Personnel=if(match(userId,"-"),"Customer Card","Splunk Datacenter Staff") | eval Direction=case(match(Room,"-in"),"Ingress",match(Room,"-out"),"Egress") | eval Room=case(match(Room,"LV-DC-2-DC-003-"),"Secure Room - 3") | fields _time Room Personnel Direction | rename _time AS "Time" | convert ctime(Time)

visualizations.title: Security Auditing - Secure Facilities
visualizations.search: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description active | lookup physical_card_user_mapping cardId AS badgeId | search description="LV-DC-2-DC-003-*" | stats count list(description) AS Room list(status) AS Status list(badgeId) AS BadgeID list(employeeId) AS userId by _time | eval Personnel=if(match(userId,"-"),"Customer Card","Splunk Datacenter Staff") | eval Direction=case(match(Room,"-in"),"Ingress",match(Room,"-out"),"Egress") | eval Room=case(match(Room,"LV-DC-2-DC-003-"),"Secure Room - 3") | fields _time Room Personnel Direction | rename _time AS "Time" | convert ctime(Time)

showcase_physical_search0003.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_physical_search0003.howToImplement:
This search relies on a RFID / Proximity badge reader system logs and lookup tables that provide further enrichment around the User-to-Badges and a Reader to Card locations.

With this data available, you can substitute in sourcetype and lookup tables to use this search.
showcase_physical_search0003.operationalize:
Security in facilities, especially Data Centers, is restricted and not only is there a need to control access but we also need to know who is accessing the facilities.

This example looks at where a badge has a high number of failures with an ACCESS-DENIED error. This could be indicative of a malicious user, or an employee with a badge problem. All of these should be immmediately actionable by facilities / security.
showcase_physical_search0003.relevance: In this example we look at how monitor abnormally high failures against a badge reader, or readers, over a time period. This can be indicative of a physical issue with a badge, or a security relevant situation where perhaps physical security is required.
showcase_physical_search0003.description: Let's find where access to badge readers has an abnormally high count within a 5 minute period.
showcase_physical_search0003.name: Security Auditing - Abnormal Failures
showcase_physical_search0003.sampleSPL: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUTNEW status | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description active | lookup physical_card_user_mapping cardId AS badgeId | eval fullName=firstName+" "+lastName | fields _time badgeId description fullName status | search status="ACCESS-DENIED" OR status="READ-SUCCESS" | streamstats count reset_on_change=true window=2 by description | search (count > 1) AND status="ACCESS-DENIED" | bin span=5m _time | stats count list(badgeId) AS Badge list(description) AS Location list(fullName) as Name by _time | where count > 1 | rename _time AS Time | convert ctime(Time) | table Time Location Badge Name

images.name: Wire_Transfer_Fraud_NewAccount.png
images.label: A particular badge having a bad day.

visualizations.title: Security Auditing - Abnormal Failures
visualizations.search: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUTNEW status | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description active | lookup physical_card_user_mapping cardId AS badgeId | eval fullName=firstName+" "+lastName | fields _time badgeId description fullName status | search status="ACCESS-DENIED" OR status="READ-SUCCESS" | streamstats count reset_on_change=true window=2 by description | search (count > 1) AND status="ACCESS-DENIED" | bin span=5m _time | stats count list(badgeId) AS Badge list(description) AS Location list(fullName) as Name by _time | where count > 1 | rename _time AS Time | convert ctime(Time) | table Time Location Badge Name

showcase_physical_search0004.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_physical_search0004.howToImplement:
This search relies on a RFID / Proximity badge reader system logs and lookup tables that provide further enrichment around the Reader to Card locations and Error Codes. Matching the hardware codes to the environmental codes in the lookup is trivial, these are well documented by most hardware manufacturers.

With this data available, you can substitute in sourcetype and lookup tables to use this search over your desired time range.
showcase_physical_search0004.operationalize: Being able to monitor badge readers and correlate environmental factors to specific events is what data analytics is all about. Being able to identify a power outage in a hallway and resolve this before a customer has problems is good.
showcase_physical_search0004.relevance: In this example we show a simple search that looks at environmental alerts coming out of our badge reader system.
showcase_physical_search0004.description: Most modern badger readers support various environmental triggers such as fire alarms, electricity failures, and backup battery failovers. This example shows how to search our RFID / Promixity badge system events for triggered environmental alarms.
showcase_physical_search0004.name: Security Auditing - Environmental Check
showcase_physical_search0004.sampleSPL: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUTNEW status | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description | fields _time badgereaderId description envAlarm errorCode powerStatus status | search envAlarm="FIRE" OR envAlarm="POWER"

showcase_physical_search0005.operationalize: Being able to monitor badge readers and correlate environmental factors to specific events is what data analytics is all about. Being able to identify a power outage in a hallway and resolve this before a customer has problems is good.
showcase_physical_search0005.relevance: In this example we show a simple search that looks at environmental alerts coming out of our badge reader system. We then perform from analytics on the data to determine an event duration and then format these in a way that can be presented.
showcase_physical_search0005.description: Most modern badger readers support various environmental triggers such as fire alarms, electricity failures, and backup battery failovers. This example shows how to search our RFID / Promixity badge system events for triggered environmental alarms and generate a nicely formated and human readable report that can be used for Compliance, Regulatory Reporting, Root Cause Analysis, etc.
showcase_physical_search0005.name: Security Auditing - Environmental Reporting
showcase_physical_search0005.sampleSPL: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUT status | search envAlarm="FIRE" OR envAlarm="POWER" | sort _time | streamstats window=0 current=false latest(_time) AS previousEventTime latest(status) AS previousStatus BY description | eval duration = _time - previousEventTime | rename status AS currentStatus | fillnull value=0 duration | eval envAlarm=case(match(envAlarm,"FIRE"),"Fire Alarm Detected in Zone",match(envAlarm,"POWER"),"Power Event Detected in Zone") | fields _time description currentStatus duration envAlarm | rename description AS "Reader Location" currentStatus AS "Lock Status" envAlarm AS "Alarm" | convert ctime(previousEventTime) | where duration > 0 | rename duration AS "Duration of Alarm (seconds)" _time AS "Time Cleared" | convert ctime("Time Cleared") | table Alarm "Reader Location" "Lock Status" "Duration of Alarm (seconds)" "Time Cleared"

showcase_physical_search0006.id: Rack Sensor Max Temperature Over Time
showcase_physical_search0006.description: Aggregated Maximum Temperature of Rack Sensors, by Time, per Server Rack.
showcase_physical_search0006.relevance: This example uses data from temperature sensors on the outlet side of a server rack. We use this data to determine the Maximum temperature range across the sensors in one of our racks and display a single value element with thresholds and colors applied to have an understanding of what our temperatures in the rack are working at.
showcase_physical_search0006.operationalize: This example uses data from temperature sensors that are installed on the racks in our data center. In this case we have three sensors per rack, on the outflow / backside of the rack.
showcase_physical_search0006.howToImplement: For this search, our data source for the transactions needs have a transaction failure status within the Process (in this case Service Activation.) Additionally, there should be a error code to human friendly description mapping that is used to enrich the source data for the final view.
showcase_physical_search0006.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_physical_search0006.name: Rack Sensor Max Temperature Over Time
showcase_physical_search0006.sampleSPL: | inputlookup physical_environmental | eval _time=strptime(dateTime, "%Y/%m/%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | eval tempF=sensorValue  | timechart fixedrange=false max(tempF) as maxTempF

showcase_physical_search0007.id: Rack Sensor Temperature Trending by Rack Sensors
showcase_physical_search0007.name: Rack Sensors Temperature Trending by Sensor
showcase_physical_search0007.description: Temperature monitoring in a rack with multiple temperature sensors, tracked over time.
showcase_physical_search0007.relevance: This example uses data from temperature sensors on the outflow / backside of a server rack. We use temperature data collected from three (3) temperature sensors and determine the average temperature, by sensor, and display a single value element trellis per sensor with thresholds and colors applied to have a easy visual understanding of the what and where our temperatures in the different areas of the rack are. This also enables us to quickly determine if they are within or outside of safe operational ranges.
showcase_physical_search0007.operationalize: This example uses data from temperature sensors that are installed on the racks in our data center. In this case we have three (3) sensors per rack, on the outflow / backside of the rack, located at the top, middle, and bottom of the rack. These will give us a general understanding of cooling capacity in our rack. When the temperature is above operational thresholds we can alert on this and proactively address the issue. This can safe time and money from outages related to thermal damage and other related issues that may can occur in hot zones.
showcase_physical_search0007.howToImplement: In this search, our data source comes from our temperature sensors which should contain a temperature value collected at regular enough intervals to create a timechart and average over the searched timerange. Additrionally the data should contain information for where the sensor is, both room and rack.
showcase_physical_search0007.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_physical_search0007.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=Rack Sensor Temperature Trending by Rack Sensors
showcase_physical_search0007.sampleSPL: | inputlookup physical_environmental | eval _time=strptime(dateTime, "%Y/%m/%d %H:%M:%S") | convert timeformat="%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S" mktime(_time) AS _time | rex field=sensorLocation "(Room(?<Room>[^\-]+)-Row(?<Row>[^-]+)-Rack(?<Rack>[^-]+)-(?<Sensor>[^-]+))" | eval Location=Room."-".Row.":".Rack."-".Sensor, tempF=sensorValue | fields _time Sensor tempF Row Rack | search Sensor=* OR Rack=* | eval Sensor=Row.Rack."-".Sensor | timechart span=1m fixedrange=false avg(tempF) AS AverageTempF by Sensor

showcase_subscriber_search0001.name: General Call Disposition Metrics
showcase_subscriber_search0001.description: This example gives us a view of our Call Flow, or Call Metrics, over a designated time period.
showcase_subscriber_search0001.howToImplement: This search will go through the CDR logs and use a lookup to enrich a disposition / error code to a human readable message. We then run the results through stats and humanize the results for easily readable report.
showcase_subscriber_search0001.relevance: This example show ours a high-level Operational Overview of our Call Metrics, or Call Flow. With this we have the capability to understand how our VOIP system is functioning in regards to call routing.
showcase_subscriber_search0001.operationalize: This example gives us a snapshot view of our current VOIP system and gives us insight to where we may be have potential technical concerns. This search utilizes CDR logs and a lookup that maps error codes to a human readable message for easier understanding.
showcase_subscriber_search0001.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0001.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | stats count values(description) AS Description by disposition | rename disposition AS Disposition count AS Count | table Description Disposition Count | eval Description=if(match(Disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",Description) | sort - Count

visualizations.title: General Call Disposition Metrics
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | stats count values(description) AS Description by disposition | rename disposition AS Disposition count AS Count | table Description Disposition Count | eval Description=if(match(Disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",Description) | sort - Count

showcase_subscriber_search0002.name: General Call Failure Metrics for CDR Analysis
showcase_subscriber_search0002.description: This search shows us all the general failures for our Customers Calls on our network.
showcase_subscriber_search0002.relevance: This search gives us a count, by type of our failed calls.
showcase_subscriber_search0002.howToImplement: This search requires CDR logs with a disposition / error field, and then a lookup with a mapping of the disposition codes to a human friendly message. From there, we calculate the number of occurences of these by the disposition and display this. This can then easily be operationalized as an alert or action.
showcase_subscriber_search0002.operationalize: This search is important because it provides us with insight to the failures our network is experiencing. We can operationalize in the form of alerts or actions.
showcase_subscriber_search0002.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0002.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="FAILED" OR disposition="CONGESTED" | stats count values(description) AS Description by disposition | rename disposition AS Disposition count AS Count | table Description Disposition Count | eval Description=if(match(Disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",Description) | sort - Count

visualizations.title: Failed Call Metrics - Simple
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="FAILED" OR disposition="CONGESTED" | stats count values(description) AS Description by disposition | rename disposition AS Disposition count AS Count | table Description Disposition Count | eval Description=if(match(Disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",Description) | sort - Count

showcase_subscriber_search0003.name: Failed Call Metrics with Enriched Details.
showcase_subscriber_search0003.description: This search look at Failed Call Metrics and provides more insight into why these calls failed.
showcase_subscriber_search0003.operationalize: This search analyzes Call Detail Records for Failed Calls, and then enriches the logs with more contextual error information for more simplistic understanding of what the errors mean and how they effect both the Voice System and potential revenue. This enables us to more effectively troubleshoot and resolve issues that are occuring, in near real-time.
showcase_subscriber_search0003.relevance: This search looks at Failed Call Metrics and provides more insight into why these calls failed based on enriched error information.
showcase_subscriber_search0003.howToImplement: This search utilizes CDR logs to look for failed calls. The failed call data is then enriched for the disposition / error messages, and a lookup for the country is performed. After this, we put the data in a report form and use this.
showcase_subscriber_search0003.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0003.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition=FAILED OR disposition=CONGESTED | eval Description=if(match(disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",description) | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | table _time src dst dstCountryCode Description disposition | rename _time AS Time src AS "Source #" dst AS "Destination #" disposition AS Disposition dstCountryCode AS "Destination Country"

visualizations.title: Failed Call Metrics - Advanced
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition=FAILED OR disposition=CONGESTED | eval Description=if(match(disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",description) | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | table _time src dst dstCountryCode Description disposition | rename _time AS Time src AS "Source #" dst AS "Destination #" disposition AS Disposition dstCountryCode AS "Destination Country"

showcase_subscriber_search0004.name: Failed Call Metrics by Geographic Location
showcase_subscriber_search0004.description: This search looks at Failed Call Metrics and provides a geographic mapping of errors during the designated time period.
showcase_subscriber_search0004.relevance: This searches provides the failed calls that are then visualized on a Splunk Geomap.
showcase_subscriber_search0004.operationalize: This search and visualization gives us and easy to understand visualization of our where the failed calls are occuring.
showcase_subscriber_search0004.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0004.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition=FAILED OR disposition=CONGESTED | eval Description=if(match(disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",description) | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName | stats count by dstCountryName  | geom geo_countries allFeatures=true featureIdfield=dstCountryName

showcase_subscriber_search0005.id: Failed Call Metrics - By Destination and Gateway
showcase_subscriber_search0005.description: General CDR Call Metrics - Failed Calls by Destination and Gateway
showcase_subscriber_search0005.relevance: Identify where calls are failing, and which routes / gateways they are routing through.
showcase_subscriber_search0005.operationalize: This search gives us insight into where calls are failing and the path the system is routing the call through. Typically routing issues can be traced back to the underlying transit network, but with this information from our CDR logs, we can gain Operational Insight into where calls are encountering issues and proactively address these.
showcase_subscriber_search0005.howToImplement:
For this search our data source for the CDR must have the Destination/Callee, along with failure status, and the path used.

From here, we use stats to help correlate fields within the event and then format the results in a easily readable report.
showcase_subscriber_search0005.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0005.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=Failed Call Metrics - By Destination and Gateway
showcase_subscriber_search0005.name: Failed Call Metrics - By Destination and Gateway
showcase_subscriber_search0005.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition=FAILED OR disposition=CONGESTED | eval Description=if(match(disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",description) | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | table src dst dstCountryCode partyBiD disposition Description _time | stats count values(dst) AS Destination values(disposition) AS Disposition values(Description) AS Description values(_time) as Time by partyBiD dst | rename partyBiD AS "Routed Path" | table Time Destination Description "Routed Path" count

visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition=FAILED OR disposition=CONGESTED | eval Description=if(match(disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",description) | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | table src dst dstCountryCode partyBiD disposition Description _time | stats count values(dst) AS Destination values(disposition) AS Disposition values(Description) AS Description values(_time) as Time by partyBiD dst | rename partyBiD AS "Routed Path" | table Time Destination Description "Routed Path" count

showcase_subscriber_search0006.description: General CDR Call Metrics - Mapping Successfully Dailed Calls
showcase_subscriber_search0006.relevance: Visual representation of where our succssfully connected calls are dialing.
showcase_subscriber_search0006.operationalize:
This search gives us insight into where our customers are calling the most in a visual representation.

From an opertational point of view, this view is a potential way to spot abnormalities in expected call behavior. And from a business persepective, we can use this information to potentially negotiate lower rates for this traffic, or perhaps raise our own prices.
showcase_subscriber_search0006.howToImplement:
For this search our data source for the CDR must have both a Source/Caller and Destination/Callee, along with succesful answer or busy status. (In this example, these two call statuses are what our metric is based on.) In addition to this, a country code is required in order to find the dailed party. In this example, we extract a country code from the dailed number, and then use a lookup to enrich this to a country name.

From here, we can use the top command to generate our data set and then choose a visualization, or reformat this into table.
showcase_subscriber_search0006.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0006.name: General Call Metrics - Geo Stats
showcase_subscriber_search0006.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="ANSWERED" OR disposition="BUSY" | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | stats count by dstCountryName | geom geo_countries allFeatures=true featureIdfield=dstCountryName

visualizations.title: General Call Metrics - Geo Stats
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="ANSWERED" OR disposition="BUSY" | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | stats count by dstCountryName | geom geo_countries allFeatures=true featureIdfield=dstCountryName

showcase_subscriber_search0011.id: General Call Metrics - Shortest Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0011.description: General CDR Call Metrics - Finding Shortest Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0011.relevance: Find our shortest call durations and their destinations. This could be used to identify fraud or abuse against the system.
showcase_subscriber_search0011.operationalize: This search gives us insight to where calls with the shortest duration time are going. From a business perspective, a high volume of calls like this to countries with high call tariffs might be indicative of malicious activity.
showcase_subscriber_search0011.howToImplement:
For this search our data source for the CDR must have both a Source/Caller and Destination/Callee. In addition to this we need to also have a country code in order to find the dailed party. In this example, we extract a country code from the dailed number, and then use a lookup to enrich this to a country name.

From here, we can use the rare command to generate our data set and then choose a visualization, or reformat this into table.
showcase_subscriber_search0011.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0011.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=General Call Metrics - Shortest Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0011.name: General Call Metrics - Shortest Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0011.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="ANSWERED" OR disposition="BUSY" | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | fields src dst dstCountryName duration | stats count list(dst) AS dst list(dstCountryName) as dstCountryName by duration src | rename duration AS "Call Duration" src AS "Caller" dst AS "Called Number" dstCountryName AS "Destination Country" | sort "Call Duration"

showcase_subscriber_search0012.id: General Call Metrics - Cumulative Minutes by Caller
showcase_subscriber_search0012.name: Cumulative Call Minutes by Subscriber.
showcase_subscriber_search0012.description: Calculate the cumulative call durations by Subscriber with a list of countries called.
showcase_subscriber_search0012.relevance: Find and calculate total minutes called and which country users have called. .
showcase_subscriber_search0012.operationalize: This search gives us insight to where our users are calling and the total duration of all their calls. From a business perspective, this information can be used for targeted marketing campaings, billing reconcilliation, capacity and service forecasting.
showcase_subscriber_search0012.howToImplement: For this search our data source for the CDR must have both a Source/Caller and Destination/Callee. In addition to this we need to also have a country code. In this example, we extract a country code from the dailed number, and then use a lookup to enrich this to a country code. From here we process this with the stats command, and use the nomv to make the dailed countries fields single value.
showcase_subscriber_search0012.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0012.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=General Call Metrics - Cumulative Minutes by Caller
showcase_subscriber_search0012.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="ANSWERED" OR billable > 0 | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | fields _time accountcode src billable dstCountryCode | convert dur2sec(billable) AS calculatedBillableS | stats values(accountcode) AS Account values(dstCountryCode) AS CalledCountries sum(eval(round((calculatedBillableS/60),0))) AS BillableMinutes by src | nomv CalledCountries | rename src AS "Caller" BillableMinutes AS "Billable Minutes" | table Account Caller CalledCountries "Billable Minutes" | sort - "Billable Minutes"

examples.name: General Call Metrics - Cumulative Minutes by Caller
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: General Call Metrics - Cumulative Minutes by Caller
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="ANSWERED" OR billable > 0 | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | fields _time accountcode src billable dstCountryCode | convert dur2sec(billable) AS calculatedBillableS | stats values(accountcode) AS Account values(dstCountryCode) AS CalledCountries sum(eval(round((calculatedBillableS/60),0))) AS BillableMinutes by src | nomv CalledCountries | rename src AS "Caller" BillableMinutes AS "Billable Minutes" | table Account Caller CalledCountries "Billable Minutes" | sort - "Billable Minutes"

showcase_subscriber_search0014.id: General Call Metrics - Daily Estimated Call Revenue
showcase_subscriber_search0014.name: Estimated Call Revenue.
showcase_subscriber_search0014.description: This example shows how to associate a monetary value to each successful call and gives us an estimated total daily revenue stream.
showcase_subscriber_search0014.relevance: This example shows how to associate a monetary value to each successful call and gives us an estimated total daily revenue stream.
showcase_subscriber_search0014.operationalize: Having a realtime understanding of Call generated revenue gives us real-time operational insight into our network and users. Having this information will enable informed decisions about capacity, billing rates, services, marketing campaigns and much more.
showcase_subscriber_search0014.howToImplement: This search requires CDR / PBX logs that contain at the minimum the log of successful outbound calls. This data is then enriched based on the destination / callee, and current billable rates are added to the results. We then calulate the call duration and associated costs with that call to the destination. Once comopleted, we then summate the total cost and report that.
showcase_subscriber_search0014.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0014.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=General Call Metrics - Daily Estimated Call Revenue
showcase_subscriber_search0014.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="ANSWERED" OR billable > 0 | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode rateFirstMinute rateMinute | fields _time accountcode src billable dstCountryCode rate* | convert dur2sec(billable) AS calculatedBillableS | eval billableMinutes = calculatedBillableS / 60 | eval billableMinutes = ceiling(billableMinutes) | eval billableMinusOne = billableMinutes - 1 | eval totalBillable = rateMinute + (billableMinusOne * rateMinute) | stats sum(totalBillable) as CallRevenue

showcase_sa_search0001.description: WIFI AP Association - General Count of Valid AP Access
showcase_sa_search0001.relevance: Find out how many users are connecting to access points.
showcase_sa_search0001.operationalize: This search gives us the ability to monitor access points and the users that are connected to them. With this data we can validate that APs are available and have capacity. We can additionally monitor who is joining the APs and utilize metrics around that.
showcase_sa_search0001.howToImplement: This search requires time series data of access to the network access points.
showcase_sa_search0001.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_sa_search0001.name: WIFI AP Association
showcase_sa_search0001.sampleSPL: | inputlookup telco_wifi_mapping | eval _time=strptime(accessTime, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | sort - _time | timechart count fixedrange=false span=15m by apID

visualizations.title: WIFI AP Association
visualizations.search: | inputlookup telco_wifi_mapping | eval _time=strptime(accessTime, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S") | sort - _time |  timechart count fixedrange=false span=15m by apID

showcase_sa_search0002.howToImplement: This search requires time series data of access to the network access points.
showcase_sa_search0002.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_sa_search0002.name: WIFI AP Geostats Access by Time
